channel.title: C/C++ Compiler
channel.description:
Hello moparscape community.
I'm learning C/C++ at the moment, well attempting to, and I can't find a compiler that works.
Can someone help me out?
Much appreiciated, Sibor

item.title: C/C++ Compiler
item.dc:creator: @Iscn Iscn
item.description:
@Iscn wrote:

A compiler comes with in an IDE. You can use some of these below.
Microsoft Visual Studio 2012

  • Sexy looking user interface
  • Supported by microsoft and in continuous updates.
    Bloodshed Dev C++
  • Simple and easy to install and get started.
  • I recommend it for new users until you get the hang of back C++ coding.
  • Updates for it ended along time ago so you can use other IDES if you want to move on to BIG projects.
    Code Blocks
  • It is pretty good and is updated.
  • Kind of like Bloodshed Dev C++ in some ways but i don’t see how it is “better”

Read full topic

item.title: C/C++ Compiler
item.dc:creator: @tnjerhgvew tnjerhgvew
item.description:
@tnjerhgvew wrote:

I think if you install visual studio 2012 to a USB you won’t need admin permissions.

Read full topic

Thanks guys for trying to help. But since I’m not administrator on this computer, dad won’t give me the password -.-, I found this

item.title: C/C++ Compiler
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“tnjerhgvew, post:16, topic:491239”][quote author=Flame_ link=topic=609473.msg4236388#msg4236388 date=1361585589]
Was just browsing the internet and stumbled across an IDE called CodeBlocks which supposedly is made for C/C++. I downloaded and looked through it, and it seems pretty nice and user friendly. Anyone with any experience with it?
[/quote]
Codeblocks is an old IDE. The latest and best IDE for any developer coding in vb.net / c# / C/c++ is Visual Studio 2012.[/quote]

Disagree. Visual Studio 2010 is much preferred. VS2012 has only been out for a little while. Just because it’s the newest doesn’t make it the greatest. As a developer, you should always prefer stability over features. Thus, it’s always recommended to stay one version behind for almost anything in this industry.

Read full topic

[/quote]
Codeblocks is an old IDE. The latest and best IDE for any developer coding in vb.net / c# / C/c++ is Visual Studio 2012.[/quote]codeblocks isn’t that old + ignore linuxers lele

Read full topic

item.title: C/C++ Compiler
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Visual Studio’s compiler (I don’t know the exact name) will be your best bet, assuming you use Windows because of what Visual Studio has to offer. I’d recommend using Visual C++ 2008 or higher.

Read full topic

item.title: C/C++ Compiler
item.dc:creator: @tnjerhgvew tnjerhgvew
item.description:
@tnjerhgvew wrote:

Flame_:

Was just browsing the internet and stumbled across an IDE called CodeBlocks which supposedly is made for C/C++. I downloaded and looked through it, and it seems pretty nice and user friendly. Anyone with any experience with it?

Codeblocks is an old IDE. The latest and best IDE for any developer coding in vb.net / c# / C/c++ is Visual Studio 2012.

Read full topic

item.title: C/C++ Compiler
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Between Microsoft compiler, GCC, and Borland, they’re all good and aren’t that hard to figure out. You’ll need to use cygwin or mingw to get gcc working, though. If you have any questions, let me know.

Read full topic
